awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Non-Black-Box Cryptography: Defending Against and Benefiting from Access to Code
awd_abstract_narration:
Cryptography is an essential and widespread tool for providing information security. Traditional cryptographic models assume only black-box, or input/output access to devices, thereby limiting the class of attacks. In practice, an attacker may obtain non-black-box access to a device and attack a particular algorithm or specific implementation such as through timing or fault injection attacks.  Exploiting non-black-box access has been a remarkably effective technique for compromising cryptosystems.

This project investigates mechanisms to protect against such non-black box attacks. The research goals of this proposal are: (1) design and analyze new algorithms for secure computation in threat models that capture non-black-box attacks, and (2) provide a better understanding of the effectiveness of non-black-box techniques in the construction of cryptosystems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The PI initiated a new area of research under this award of constructing non-malleable codes against tampering within a class C, where C corresponds to well-studied complexity classes in the literature. The results from this research included constructions of non-malleable codes for NC^0, bounded depth bounded fan-in circuits, AC^0, decision trees, streaming space-bounded tampering, bounded polynomial time/size, and bounded parallel time tampering. This line of research led to 11 publications, including 6 top-tier publications (FOCS, EUROCRYPT, CRYPTO) and over 270 citations.

Other results under this award include black-box and non-black-box separations of cryptographic primitives, as well as side-channel attacks and resilience for machine learning and data processing algorithms, for a total of 5 publicatons, including 2 top-tier publications (USENIX and ICLR).

More recently the PI's research has focused on analyzing the effect of side-channel information on the concrete security of post-quantum cryptosystems for a total of 6 publications, including 3 top-tier publications (CRYPTO and CCS).

This award has funded graduate research assistanceships for four PhD students, three of whom have now graduated and are working in research positions. It has funded professional development for students to travel to conferences and workshops and to present their work at leading institutions. 

With regards to broader impacts, the PI has led REU projects related to the main research thrusts of this award in Summers 2017, 2018 and 2022. She has also mentored an undergraduate researcher in Summer 2019 on a project related to side-channel attacks on data processing algorithms.  The PI is currently leading a Gemstones team consisting of seven University of Maryland honors students on the topic of concrete security of post-quantum cryptosystems in the presence of side-channel information. The PI incorporates research on side-channel attacks in her undergraduate security course and includes a unit on post-quantum cryptography in her undergraduate cryptography course. She has also been actively involved in outreach to women and industry.

As part of one of the projects, an open source toolkit for analyzing the concrete security of post-quantum cryptosystems has been released and is available online.


Last Modified: 06/05/2023
Modified by: Dana Dachman-Soled
